tossups.question: This novel references an earlier story by the author in which a 92-year-old matriarch dies while listing out her possessions. In this novel, a girl brings 72 people to her family’s house without warning after being sent away when a woman known as “the Elephant” wins an eating contest. A woman in this novel is instructed by Death to knit her own funeral shroud and covers her burnt hand with a black bandage. In this novel, a plague of (*) insomnia is started by Rebeca, who eats dirt and carries around a bag containing her parents’ bones. The fortune-teller and madam Pilar Ternara lives to over 140 in this novel. The matriarch Úrsula helps found a “city of mirrors” with José Arcadio in, for 10 points, what novel about the Buendía family’s time in Macondo, by Gabriel García Márquez?
tossups.answer: One Hundred Years of Solitude (The first line refers to “Big Mama’s Funeral.”) <AR, Long Fiction>
tossups.answer_formatted: One Hundred Years of Solitude <AR, Long Fiction>
acceptable: One Hundred Years of Solitude <AR, Long Fiction>
One Hundred Years of Solitude <AR, Long Fiction>
tossups.metadata: The first line refers to “Big Mama’s Funeral.”

tossups.question: Edgar Fonseca designed one of these buildings in a Mayan-revival style covered in small, square windows. Another of these buildings is the center of a complex containing the Richard Neutra-designed Arboretum. A third of these buildings is cooled partially by a reflecting pool on its roof and is surrounded by 16 hyperboloid concrete columns. That white example of these buildings, which resembles a crown, was designed by (*) Oscar Niemeyer (“NEE-my-er”). It’s not a house, but Phillip Johnson designed a glass example of these buildings in Garden Grove, California, called the “crystal” one. Before the Eiffel Tower was completed, the tallest building in the world was a 500-foot-tall example of these buildings in Cologne. For 10 points, name these buildings that serve as the seats of dioceses including Brasília and Orange County.
tossups.answer: cathedrals [prompt on churches] <JM, Other Arts: Architecture>

tossups.question: A set of ancient treatises named for this concept state that its principles should be learned during brahmacharya (“BRAH-muh-CHAR-yuh”), the first of the four ashramas (“ASH-ruh-muhs”). In a story illustrating this concept, Yudhisthira (“YOO-dish-teer”) refused to enter heaven without his loyal dog, who was actually a god named for this concept in disguise. Much like Hindus, many Buddhists use the word for this concept as an alternate name for the king of the narakas, who is otherwise named Lord (*) Yama, or death. This concept, which is often represented by an eight-spoked wheel, is exemplified by the obligations that arise on account of one’s varna, or caste. In general, it refers to that which is consistent with rta (“RR-tuh”), or the order of the universe. For 10 points, give this Sanskrit term that is often translated as “duty” or “law.”
tossups.answer: dharma [accept dharmachakra or wheel of dharma] <WA, Religion>

tossups.question: After an invader was granted this title, he was ordered to kiss his overlord’s foot, but did so by bringing that overlord’s foot up to his mouth, thus making him fall over. That first man to hold this title, known in sagas as Hrólfr the Walker, was given it in exchange for agreeing to stop pillaging the lands of Charles the Simple. This title’s holders include a man born to Herleva, the (*) mistress of Robert the Magnificent, and a Viking of unknown birth named Rollo. Another holder of this title was nicknamed “the bastard” and defeated an exhausted rival who had just won the Battle of Stamford Bridge in an engagement on Senlac Hill. For 10 points, identify this specific title of nobility held by the winner of the Battle of Hastings, William the Conqueror.
tossups.answer: Duke of Normandy [prompt on duke or other answers that indicate a ruler of Normandy] <JM, European History>
tossups.answer_formatted: Duke of Normandy <JM, European History> [prompt on duke or other answers that indicate a ruler of Normandy]
promptable: other answers that indicate a ruler of Normandy

tossups.question: The speaker of a poem reminds one of these people about three scrolls he had painted while blind, and earlier gives one of these people a food “swelled, heavy as sadness, / and sweet as love.” “No one ever thanked” one of these people who “got up early” on “Those Winter Sundays” in a poem by Robert Hayden. In a third poem, a photo depicts one of these people “[standing] at the blackboard” with “A cleft in your chin instead of your foot.” That poem tells one of these people “There’s a (*) stake in your fat black heart” and compares him to a “black shoe.” A poem beginning “You do not do, you do not do” likens a “model” of one of these people to “A man in black with a Meinkampf look.” For 10 points, Sylvia Plath declared “you bastard, I’m through” in a poem addressing what family member?
tossups.answer: father [or dad; or “Daddy”; prompt on parent] (The first poem is Li-Young Lee’s “Persimmons.”) <RK, Poetry>
tossups.metadata: The first poem is Li-Young Lee’s “Persimmons.”

tossups.question: Biosynthesis of this molecule is commonly studied in the bacterium Komagataeibacter xylinus. The amount of this molecule can be quantified by mixing it with anthrone and calculating its absorbance at a wavelength of 635 nanometers. A bright blue solution of tetra-ammine-di-aqua-copper(II), or Schweizer’s reagent, is commonly used to dissolve this polymer. Proteins are transferred onto a membrane of PVDF or a nitrated derivative of this polymer in a (*) western blot. Carbon disulfide is used in xanthation, one step of a process in which this polymer is converted into rayon fibers. This polymer is composed of D-glucose monomers joined by beta 1,4 linkages. For 10 points, name this polysaccharide that comprises the cell walls of plants.
tossups.answer: cellulose <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.question: A polyomavirus that infects cells that detect this sense can trigger malignancy in its host when the helicase domain of its LT antigen is deleted. A sensor for this sense in crayfish was one of the first characterized examples of stochastic resonance in biology. The YbdG and Piezo channels transduct this sense. The carotid sinus and aortic arch are two locations that include receptors of this sense known as baroreceptors. Receptors for this sense are divided into (*) slow and fast-adapting and are innervated by A-beta fibers. Those receptors include Merkel cells and the onion-shaped Pacinian corpuscle. Receptors for this sense can be found in the stratum basale or within hair follicles. For 10 points, name this sense that is used to detect movement or pressure on the skin.
tossups.answer: touch [or stretch or mechanoreception; accept pressure until read] <RN, Biology: Medicine>
tossups.answer_formatted: touch <RN, Biology: Medicine> [or stretch or mechanoreception; accept pressure until read]

tossups.question: This thinker’s work was so interesting to Marie de Gournay that she became his “adopted daughter” and later translated many of his most famous works. This thinker claimed that humans have “more need for lead than for wings” to pioneer a method of contemplation. This thinker, who claimed that to study philosophy is to learn to die, wrote that eating a dead human is better than eating a live one in a work “On (*) Cannibals.” Another of his works defends a Spanish author’s Natural Theology. The motto “What do I know?” was used by this author, who pioneered a new form of writing in works like Apology for Raymond Sebond. For 10 points, name this provincial Frenchman who used the French word for “attempt” to name his Essays.
tossups.answer: Michel de Montaigne [or Michel Eyquem de Montaigne] <ML, Phil/Thought>
tossups.answer_formatted: Michel de Montaigne <ML, Phil/Thought> [or Michel Eyquem de Montaigne]

tossups.question: This dynasty once paid a mercenary army for each disembodied head, after which the mercenaries proceeded to massacre a bunch of this dynasty’s subjects to collect the bounty. That incident is recounted in Frederick Wakeman’s history of the transition of this dynasty to its successor, titled The Great Enterprise. This dynasty is postulated to have “discovered the world” by the pseudohistorian Gavin Menzies. Most silver mined in the Americas ultimately went to purchase (*) goods from this dynasty, such as from its official kilns at Jingdezhen (“jing-duh-jun”). Its Yongle (“yong-luh”) emperor supervised the creation of historical texts from a palace complex built under it, the Forbidden City. The eunuch (“YOO-nuck”) Zheng He (“jung huh”) sailed the seas on behalf of, for 10 points, what dynasty whose official history was written under its successors, the Qing (“ching”)?
tossups.answer: Ming dynasty <JM, Historiography>

tossups.question: In one work, this author wrote “To describe my mother would be to write about a hurricane in its perfect power.” In a work by this author, Henry Reed delivers the valedictorian speech “To Be or Not to Be” before singing “Lift Ev’ry Voice and Sing.” This author’s time as a university administrator in Ghana is related in the book All God’s Children Need Traveling Shoes. This author described moving in with Daddy Clidell and Vivian Baxter Johnson prior to conducting a (*) San Francisco streetcar and becoming pregnant in high school. She described going mute after being raped by Mr. Freeman at the age of eight in a memoir titled for a line from Paul Laurence Dunbar’s poem “Sympathy” and mostly set in Stamps, Arkansas. For 10 points, what African-American poet wrote the autobiography I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings?
tossups.answer: Maya Angelou [or Marguerite Annie Johnson] <AR, Misc Lit>

tossups.question: The concept of adiabatic invariants was first proposed while studying how altering one of these systems named for Rayleigh and Lorentz affected its quantum state. Coupling between two degrees of freedom lead to alternating periods of solely one type of motion in one of these systems named for Wilberforce. The complete expression for this system features the integral of 1 over the square root of one minus k-squared sine-squared theta, or the (*) elliptic integral of the first kind. Two of these systems joined end-to-end display chaotic behavior. A simple one of these systems has a period of [read slowly] “2 pi times the square root of length divided by gravitational acceleration” and therefore has period independent of its mass. For 10 points, name these systems that consist of a free-swinging mass suspended from a point.
tossups.answer: pendulums [or pendula; prompt on oscillator, harmonic oscillator, simple harmonic oscillator, or SHO] <RN, Physics>
tossups.answer_formatted: pendulums <RN, Physics> [or pendula; prompt on oscillator, harmonic oscillator, simple harmonic oscillator, or SHO]
promptable: oscillator, harmonic oscillator, simple harmonic oscillator,

tossups.question: It’s not cloth, but Stephen Rockel wrote a book on the role of the Nyamwezi people as a “nation of porters” for this good. William Fagg coined the term “Afro-Portuguese” to refer to sculptures made from this good in the Kongo Kingdom for European consumption. It’s not slaves, but Tippu Tip became rich by extorting tribute in this good from Central African states and then reselling it. Along with bronze, this good was used to make royal altars in the (*) Benin Kingdom. The Sheldrick Trust was founded to combat the trade in this good, whose 1989 ban led to a recovery in the population of the animal it is derived from. For 10 points, name this good that was frequently imported from Africa for use in billiard balls and piano keys in the 19th century.
tossups.answer: ivory <JM, World History>

tossups.question: This is the musical form of a tintinnabuli piece for strings and bells whose theme is a descending A minor scale, Arvo Pärt’s (“pairt’s”) Cantus in Memoriam Benjamin Britten. The comes (“KOH-mays”) plays for a longer interval than the dux in examples of this form “by augmentation.” The “Quaerendo invenietis” (“kwye-REN-doh in-ven-YET-ees”) movement from The Musical Offering exemplifies a variety of this form in which an inverted melody accompanies the main theme, its “mirror” variety. In a piece (*) titled for this form, the descending notes [read slowly] “D, A, B, F-sharp” begin an eight-note ground bass ostinato. Nine movements in this form, starting “at the unison,” make up every third Goldberg Variation. If all voices in this form are identical, it is called a round. For 10 points, what form of imitative counterpoint titles a D major piece by Johann Pachelbel?
tossups.answer: canons [accept mensuration canon or canon by augmentation or mirror canon or Canon in D; prompt on rounds; prompt on imitative counterpoint until read; prompt on Cantus until read by asking “what is the form?”] <WA, Classical/Opera>
tossups.answer_formatted: canons <WA, Classical/Opera> [accept mensuration canon or canon by augmentation or mirror canon or Canon in D; prompt on rounds; prompt on imitative counterpoint until read; prompt on Cantus until read by asking “what is the form?]

tossups.question: One of these devices is operated using the OpenQASM (“open-kasm”) software package. These devices can accomplish period-finding using the same methods proposed to solve Simon’s problem. These devices often map basis sets using mutually orthogonal matrices with Hadamard gates. Information used by these devices can be represented by a (*) Bloch sphere and can exist in superpositions when stored in their registers. These devices would be capable of breaking RSA encryption by running Shor’s algorithm. For 10 points, what machines can exploit entanglement for calculations, and as such are more suited for certain tasks than classical computers?
tossups.answer: quantum computers [or quantum supercomputers; accept quantum after “computers” is read; prompt on computers; prompt on qubits or quantum gates or quantum chips or QPUs or quantum processing units] <WA, Computer Science>
tossups.answer_formatted: quantum computers <WA, Computer Science> [or quantum supercomputers; accept quantum after “computers” is read; prompt on computers; prompt on qubits or quantum gates or quantum chips or QPUs or quantum processing units]

tossups.question: The largest munitions plant in the US during World War II was named for the mascot of this state’s flagship university and based in its city of Baraboo. Regulations on streams were waved for the recent construction of a plant near the town of Mount Pleasant in this state that, despite receiving 5 billion dollars in subsidies, will likely never employ anywhere close to 13,000 workers making LCD screens. In 2018, a large GM plant was demolished in this state’s town of (*) Janesville. Foxconn is currently building a huge plant in this state. Such companies as Pabst Blue Ribbon, Schlitz, and Miller have historically produced beer in this state’s largest city, leading to the naming of its professional baseball team. For 10 points, what state is home to former speaker Paul Ryan, as well as the Milwaukee Brewers?
tossups.answer: Wisconsin <JM, Geography>

tossups.question: Libertarian theorist Hans-Hermann Hoppe called his observation that “internally liberal states” most often go to war the “paradox of” this policy. A “search of investment” is postulated as the “taproot of” this policy in J. A. Hobson’s classic “study” of it. John Gallagher and Ronald Robinson distinguished between “formal” and “informal” means by which this policy was pursued in an article about “[this policy] of free trade.” (*) Vladimir Lenin called this policy “the highest stage of capitalism.” The sequel to Orientalism by Edward Said (“sa-EED”) attempts to analyze western culture’s links to this concept, which he claims persisted after the end of de jure colonialism. For 10 points, name this policy pursued by Wilhelmine Germany, Meiji Japan, Victorian Britain, and other nations wishing to expand their borders or influence.
tossups.answer: imperialism [accept word forms such as imperialist policy; accept empire; prompt on colonialism or word forms until read] <AA, Social Science: Political>
tossups.answer_formatted: imperialism <AA, Social Science: Political> [accept word forms such as imperialist policy; accept empire; prompt on colonialism or word forms until read]
acceptable: word forms such as imperialist policy

tossups.question: An artist claimed that his paintings of these objects were meant to create the “illusion of an endless hole” without “horizon or bank.” Several paintings of these objects were offered to that artist’s home country for a “monument to peace” to celebrate the end of World War I. An artist spent most of his last three decades of life painting these objects, which became more yellow and abstract over time due to his (*) cataracts, as seen in Le Bassin Aux Nymphéas (“luh bah-SAN oh nam-fay-AH”). A number of these objects are found beneath the title structure of an 1897 painting of a Japanese Bridge, which is among the over 200 paintings of these objects executed at the artist’s estate at Giverny (“zhee-vair-NEE”). For 10 points, name these aquatic flowers often depicted by Claude Monet.
tossups.answer: water lilies [prompt on flowers] <WA, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.question: This author quipped a man should be able to “take a glass of wine by his own fireside,” referencing the burning of his theatre. This author, who acquired the Drury Lane theatre from David Garrick, used George Villiers’s The Rehearsal as the basis for a play about a rehearsal of the play The Spanish Armada. This author’s debut play, set in the town of Bath, failed due to the poor performance of the character Sir Lucius (*) O’Trigger. Lines describing “an allegory on the banks of the Nile” and “the very pineapple of politeness” appear in a play by this author in which Jack Absolute disguises himself as the penniless Ensign Beverley to pursue Lydia Languish, whose guardian is the comic Mrs. Malaprop. For 10 points, identify this Irish playwright of The Critic and The Rivals.
tossups.answer: Richard Sheridan [or Richard Brinsley Sheridan] <AR, Drama>

tossups.question: Speaking about this character, a group of elderly citizens lament that the gods have created a “mighty wild bull, head raised.” After asserting the right of first night, this character is challenged to a wrestling match. This character is known as “He who saw the deep,” as he once tied stones to his feet and went underwater. He sends a temple (*) prostitute to seduce a man who grazes grass and drinks water from a watering hole like an animal. This man seeks an immortality-granting plant after the death of his wild-man friend, with whom he fights in the Cedar Forest against the monster Humbaba. For 10 points, name this friend of Enkidu and title character of a Mesopotamian epic, a two-thirds divine King of Uruk.
tossups.answer: Gilgamesh <ML, Myths/Legends>

tossups.question: After a massacre named for one of these places, Pedro de Aviles left a placard reading “Hanged not as Frenchmen, but as Lutherans.” William Trevers distributed smallpox blankets during negotiations after a battle named for another of these places during Pontiac’s Rebellion. That one of these places, built by France between the Allegheny and Monongahela rivers, was renamed during the Seven Years’ War after William (*) Pitt the Elder following its British capture. Examples of these places in Florida include one named “Caroline” after Charles IX of France and one named for Charles Myers. Another of these places near Lake Champlain was seized by Vermonters in May 1775. For 10 points, name these defensive places, one of which was captured by the Green Mountain Boys and named Ticonderoga.
tossups.answer: forts [accept fortresses or castillos; accept Negro Fort, Fort Myers, or Fort Caroline; prompt on answers such as settlements or towns by asking “what were those towns called?”] <JM, US History>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses
tossups.answer_formatted: forts <JM, US History> If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions. Bonuses [accept fortresses or castillos; accept Negro Fort, Fort Myers, or Fort Caroline; prompt on answers such as settlements or towns by asking “what were those towns called?]
acceptable: forts <JM, US History>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses
forts <JM, US History>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: This color is traditionally worn by the ensemble in Act 3 of La Bayadère (“ba-ya-DAIR”) as they portray the residents of the “Kingdom of the Shades.” For 10 points each:
answers: Odette (from Swan Lake) <RR, Other Arts: Dance>
parts: Name this color worn by dancers in a traditional ballet blanc (“blonk”). It is also worn by the dancers from the Dance of the Snowflakes in The Nutcracker.

A ballet blanc scene in Act 2 of this ballet is populated by ghostly maidens who were abandoned by their lovers, called wilis (“WEE-lees”). They are eventually joined by this ballet’s title character, who dies of a broken heart after Albrecht abandons her.
In performances of another ballet, a dancer usually wears black to perform the role of Odile (“oh-DEEL”) and wears white to perform the role of this other character.

bonuses.leadin: Marketers often take advantage of “cognitive” examples of these phenomena, such as by framing in terms of loss instead of gain. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this term for systematic distortions in thinking, such as only seeking out information that confirms one’s established opinions.

One bias often exploited in marketing is this effect, in which a positive judgment about a person or organization in one domain distorts perceptions in other domains. Nisbett and Wilson’s study of this effect found that, if a teacher was friendly to students, their European accent would be considered appealing.
The halo effect was named by this psychologist, who created a number of puzzle boxes to study animals and postulated the “law of effect” regarding behavior conditioning.

bonuses.leadin: This language was invented by the Polish academic L. L. Zamenhof, who was inspired by the polyglot nature of his boyhood hometown. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this widely spoken constructed language. Its draws much of its vocabulary from Romance languages, including its name, which sounds a lot like the Spanish word for “hoping.”

This earlier attempt at an international auxiliary language was invented by the priest Johann Schleyer. This language, whose name means “world talk,” was likely doomed by its excessive use of umlauts.

Somehow, the child abuse authorities never went after linguist d’Armond Speers for teaching his son this fictional tongue as a first language. The opera ’u’ (“ooh”) is written in this language created by Marc Okrand, whose second-language speakers include Saavik.

bonuses.leadin: The decay constant in this equation is equal to the natural log of 2 divided by the isotope’s half-life. For 10 points each:
answers: particle in a box [or infinite potential well or infinite square well; do not accept or prompt on “finite square well”] <RN, Physics>
parts: Name this equation that relates a radioactive isotope’s decay constant to the energy of the helium nuclei that it emits.

The Geiger–Nutall law is used to study this type of radioactive decay, which emits a helium nucleus. Studies of this type of decay helped determine that an atom’s positive charge resided in its nucleus by Rutherford.

The Geiger–Nutall law can be derived by considering an alpha particle in this model system, which has infinite potential everywhere except for a confined region with zero energy. The wavefunction for this system are all sine functions.
answers_formatted: particle in a box <RN, Physics> [or infinite potential well or infinite square well; do not accept or prompt on "finite square well"]

bonuses.leadin: An essay praising the coral worm’s “spirit of prophecy” and the bee’s problem-solving ability describes how one of these animals opens a door daily, marking the shadowy “boundary between instinct and reason.” For 10 points each:
answers: black cats [prompt on cats by asking “what color?”]
Blackwood [accept “How to Write a Blackwood Article” or Blackwood’s Magazine or Algernon Blackwood] <NC, Short Fiction>
parts: Give this color and type of animal. The shriek of one of these animals reveals the narrator of a story had “walled the monster up within the tomb” after earlier gouging out the eye of one of these animals named Pluto.
The essay “Instinct vs. Reason – A Black Cat” was written by this author of macabre stories like “The Black Cat” and “The Tell-Tale Heart.”

Poe wrote a satirical story on how to write for an Edinburgh magazine with this name that serialized Heart of Darkness. Two men travel down the Danube in the horror story “The Willows” by an author with this surname.
answers_formatted: Blackwood <NC, Short Fiction> [accept How to Write a Blackwood Article or Blackwood’s Magazine or Algernon Blackwood]
acceptable: How to Write a Blackwood Article

bonuses.leadin: Rosalind Krauss’s 1985 essay titled for the “originality” of this concept begins by examining the “concept of a copy” with an exhibition of freshly made casts of Rodin sculptures. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this concept. Another essay illustrates this concept with the poetry of T. S. Eliot and the art of Picasso, which the author contrasts with the mass culture of a Tin Pan Alley song and Saturday Evening Post cover.
Clement Greenberg’s essay suggests a peasant would prefer the kitsch works of this Russian realist over the avant-garde Picasso. He painted Barge Haulers on the Volga.
Jean-François Lyotard’s essay “The Sublime and the Avant-Garde” highlights the “chromatic sensations” of this Post-Impressionist, who painted many still-lifes and scenes of Mont Sainte-Victoire.

bonuses.leadin: In glycogen synthesis, glucose must first be activated by attachment to this molecule before it can be added to a growing glycogen chain. For 10 points each:
answers: phosphate ion [or phosphate group] <RN, Biology: Biochem>
parts: Name this molecule. In the final step of the Leloir pathway, the enzyme GALE catalyzes the epimerization of galactose bound to this molecule into glucose bound to this molecule, which can then enter glycolysis.

Glycogen synthesis begins with the attachment of UDP-glucose monomers onto this amino acid on the protein glycogenin. Patients with phenylketonuria are unable to synthesize this amino acid from phenylalanine.
Tyrosine is a common substrate for kinases, which attach this ion to proteins. This ion’s formula is PO4-three-minus.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about depictions of feminist utopias, for 10 points each.
answers: Charlotte Perkins Gilman (That story is “The Yellow Wallpaper.”)
insane asylum [or mental institution; or psychiatric hospital; prompt on hospital]
Norway [or Kingdom of Norway] (That series is Sigrid Undset’s Kristin Lavransdatter trilogy.) <RK, Long Fiction>
parts: Three bumbling male explorers discover a peaceful all-female society in this author’s novel Herland. She wrote a story about a woman who hallucinates after being prescribed “rest cure” by her husband.

In Marge Piercy’s Woman on the Edge of Time, Connie Ramos communicates with a future devoid of hierarchy from within one of these places. Ken Kesey’s novel One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest is set in one of these places.

The boy Petronius attempts to upheave a matriarchal society comprised of “wim” and “menwim” in Egalia’s Daughters, by an author from this country. A series of novels from this country center on a headstrong Catholic woman during the Middle Ages.
answers_formatted: insane asylum [or mental institution; or psychiatric hospital; prompt on hospital]
metadata: That series is Sigrid Undset’s Kristin Lavransdatter trilogy.

bonuses.leadin: Ovid claims that this man’s mother fell in love with his father due to the influence of the Furies, as Cupid would never have been responsible for such an act. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who was born after his later lover, Aphrodite, cursed Myrrha to lust after her father Cinyras (“SIN-uh-russ”). The soils fertilized by this man’s blood grew into the anemone flower after he died.
So-called “gardens of Adonis” contained anemone, fennel and this other plant. In one story, Hera ate this food before she gave birth to the messenger goddess Hebe (“HEE-bee”).
Adonis was gored by one of these animals. Meleager (“mell-ee-AY-gur”) and Atalanta participated in a hunt for another of these animals sent by Artemis to ravage Calydon.

bonuses.leadin: Different societies have radically different views on cousin marriage. For 10 points each:
answers: South Korea [or Republic of Korea or Daehan Minguk; prompt on Korea]
Amish people [or Pennsylvania Dutch; do not accept or prompt on “Dutch”] <WA, Geography>
parts: Over the centuries, Gujarati Hindus have severely disapproved of this group’s practice of intra-family marriage, termed khvedodah (“kh’VEH-doh-dah”). This term refers to Zoroastrians who live in India.

Due to a strong cousin marriage taboo, this nation’s Civil Code once banned marriages between people with the same last name. This was seriously inconvenient, as over half this country’s population is named Park, Lee, or Kim.

Though these people have a strong taboo on cousin marriage, studies have found that two randomly selected members of “Old Order” groups of them, such as those in Lancaster County, would have an average inbreeding coefficient greater than that of two second cousins.
answers_formatted: South Korea [or Republic of Korea or Daehan Minguk; prompt on Korea]
Amish people <WA, Geography> [or Pennsylvania Dutch; do not accept or prompt on "Dutch"]

bonuses.leadin: Paul Pelliot has been criticized for looting massive numbers of texts from a library in this country, which was later destroyed in its civil war. For 10 points each:
answers: China [or People’s Republic of China; or PRC; or Zhongguo]
parts: Name this country where the Terracotta Army was found in a farmfield in 1974 and archaeologists have uncovered oracle bones from the Shang dynasty.
The Terracotta Army was uncovered in this ancient capital of China in modern Shaanxi province. Either the ancient name of the city or the modern city it is found within is acceptable.

Pelliot rose to fame after introducing this site to the west. This site in Gansu province is sometimes also named for the thousand Buddha statues found in it. The Hungarian-British archaeologist Aurel Stein also removed a number of manuscripts from this site.

bonuses.leadin: Popular examples of these substances include organic peroxides such as di-tert-butyl peroxide, which easily decompose to form two oxygen radicals. For 10 points each:
answers: nitrogen gas [or N2; or dinitrogen gas]
parts: AIBN is an example of what kind of substance that undergoes a homolytic bond cleavage in order to start a radical reaction?
The decomposition of AIBN is driven by the release of this molecule. In the Haber process, this diatomic gas reacts with hydrogen to form ammonia, and this gas is the most common in the atmosphere.

Another popular initiator contains this metal bonded to three butyl groups and a hydride. This metal is bonded to several butyl and isothiocyanate groups in Otera’s catalyst, which is used for transesterification.

bonuses.leadin: This empire supplied its cities with water using massive reservoirs called barays (“buh-RYES”). For 10 points each:
answers: stepwells [accept baoli, baori, vav, kalyani, or barav; prompt on wells]
Sri Lanka [or Ceylon or Serendib] <JM, World History>
parts: Name this empire whose capital city of Angkor used two such barays, whose drying out was a major cause of its collapse.

In order to guarantee water supply, medieval Indian empires sponsored the construction of these structures, which contain labyrinthine stairways that allow people to walk directly down to the water table. The Agrasen one of these structures still supplies water to New Delhi.

A massive water tank called the “Sea of Parakrama” was built on this island by its namesake medieval ruler. That tank supplied water to his capital of Polonnaruwa, and would later provide water during the era of this island’s Kandy Kingdom.
answers_formatted: stepwells [accept baoli, baori, vav, kalyani, or barav; prompt on wells]

bonuses.leadin: Name these writers who highlighted workers’ struggles in mid-20th-century California, for 10 points each.
answers: John Steinbeck [or John Ernst Steinbeck Jr.]
Chester Himes [or Chester Bomar Himes] <WA, Misc Lit>
parts: This author depicted the struggles of migrant laborers George and Lennie in his novella Of Mice and Men.

This author included labor journalist Carey McWilliam’s novel Southern California Country in his 28-volume American Folkways series. This author of Tobacco Road collaborated with photographer Margaret Bourke-White on the documentary series You Have Seen Their Faces.
This author’s novel If He Hollers Let Him Go depicts the struggles of a black shipyard worker in Los Angeles. Nine “hardboiled” novels make up his Harlem Detective series.

bonuses.leadin: The publication of the Bahr-Papier (“BAR-pah-PEER”) exposed collusion between a minister of this man and diplomat Valentin Falin. For 10 points each:
answers: Willy Brandt (“VILL-ee BRONT”) [or Herbert Ernst Karl Frahm]
Social Democratic Party of Germany [or SPD; ir Sozialdemokratische Partei Deutschlands] <ML, European History>
parts: Name this world leader. Foreign policy initiatives during his tenure included an attempt to normalize relations with the government of Willi Stoph.
Brandt cried on a state visit to this city in what is known as this city’s namesake “knee fall.” This city also names a pact between the Soviet Union and its allies signed in response to NATO.
Brandt was the first postwar prime minister of West Germany from this party, who are the traditional rivals of the Christian Democratic Union.
answers_formatted: Social Democratic Party of Germany <ML, European History> [or SPD; ir Sozialdemokratische Partei Deutschlands]
acceptable: Social Democratic Party of Germany <ML, European History>
Social Democratic Party of Germany <ML, European History>

bonuses.leadin: Most Riedel (“REE-dull”) shear structures are produced by the movement of these things. For 10 points each:
answers: strike-slip faults [or wrench faults or tear faults or transcurrent faults; prompt on faults or slip faults or transform faults by asking “what type of faults?”]
parts: Name these vertical fractures in the Earth’s surface. They are named for having movements that are almost entirely horizontal, in contrast with “oblique” and “dip” counterparts that often move vertically.
One example of a strike-slip fault is this fault that runs through California along the boundary of the Pacific and North American plates.
This geologist, who originally posited the transform fault, also posited that the Hawaiian Islands were formed by a tectonic plate dragging over a hotspot.
answers_formatted: strike-slip faults [or wrench faults or tear faults or transcurrent faults; prompt on faults or slip faults or transform faults by asking “what type of faults?]

bonuses.leadin: The melody of a piece for this instrument by Francisco Tárrega, the Grand Vals, was used in a popular Nokia ringtone. For 10 points each:
answers: guitar [or guitarra; accept classical guitar or acoustic guitar]
Fernando Sor [or Ferran Sor; or Fernando Sors or Fernando Sort or Fernando Sorts] <WA, Classical/Opera>
parts: Name this string instrument of Spanish origin. Its music often accompanies flamenco dancing along with palmas, or hand clapping.

Unlike his Mandolin Concerto in C major, this Baroque composer’s Lute Concerto in D major is usually played today on the guitar. His short Double Trumpet Concerto in C major, RV 537, is one of the earliest solo brass pieces.

This master Spanish guitarist, who refused to play with his ring finger or fingernails, composed Variations on a Theme of Mozart. His book Méthode pour la Guitare (“may-TUD poor la ghee-TAR”) was one of the most popular pedagogical books of the 19th century.
answers_formatted: Fernando Sor <WA, Classical/Opera> [or Ferran Sor; or Fernando Sors or Fernando Sort or Fernando Sorts]

bonuses.leadin: This time period got its name from reporter Benjamin Russell during the president’s tour of the northeast. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this period of American history. The first two-party system collapsed before this period in which the Democratic-Republicans were the only party.

This president met people during the “Great Goodwill Tours” of the Era of Good Feelings dressed in Revolutionary War garb. This president names a doctrine that forbade European countries from interfering in Latin America.

Due to low turnout in the nominating convention for the 1820 election, this person offered a resolution adjourning the meeting. This only Vice President elected by the Senate used the slogan “Rumpsy dumpsy, rumpsy dumpsy, [this person] killed Tecumseh.”

bonuses.leadin: A poem titled for the “Solitude” of this time describes how the speaker “lay in a drowse” as “the blown flowers fell and filled my lap.” For 10 points each:
answers: night [accept “The Solitude of Night” or “Quiet Night Thoughts”]
Li Bai [or Li Po; or Li Bo]
waking up drunk [or equivalents; accept “Waking From Drunkenness on a Spring Day”] <RK, Poetry>
parts: Give this time that titles an oft-memorized poem by the same author, whose speaker mistakes some light for “frost on the ground” before lowering his head and thinking of home.
This Tang poet mused on moonlight in his poems “The Solitude of Night” and “Quiet Night Thoughts.”

Li Bai’s “The Solitude of Night” describes how “The birds had all gone to their nests” after the speaker does this. Li wrote “Life in the world is but a big dream” in a poem titled for this action “on a Spring Day.”
answers_formatted: night [accept The Solitude of Night or Quiet Night Thoughts]
waking up drunk <RK, Poetry> [or equivalents; accept Waking From Drunkenness on a Spring Day]
acceptable: Waking From Drunkenness on a Spring Day

bonuses.leadin: Christ’s quadruple role as savior, healer, baptizer, and coming king lends its name to the Foursquare Church founded by this woman. For 10 points each:
answers: evangelical Christianity [or evangelism or evangelist Christianity]
parts: Name this woman who proselytized (“PROSS-lit-tized”) largely among migrants in her home state of California.
McPherson’s teachings exemplified this sort of Christianity, which is named for the act of spreading the message of Christ. This Christian movement is often referred to as “born-again” Christianity.

Aimee Semple McPherson was a founding figure in this evangelical Protestant denomination, whose spread began after a meeting organized by the black preacher George Seymour, the Azusa Street Revival. The Charismatic movement spreads practices similar to those of this church.
